subject: Trigger: make dbus properties writable
commitMessage:
Trigger: make dbus properties writable

This change allows to modify 'Sensors', 'ReportNames' and 'Thresholds'
dbus properties of Trigger interface. They are required by Redfish to
implement PATCH functionality for Trigger schema.

Some backend changes were required to enable this functionality, and as
such few improvements were made for existing code:
- NumericThreshold and DiscreteThreshold now have common implementation
  where it was possible.
- Internal sensor info structure for Trigger is now the same as the one
  used for Report. This resulted in breaking compatibility with previous
  Trigger persistency data.
- Added getInfo / getParams methods for Sensor and Threshold interfaces.
  They are used by Trigger dbus getters and persistency mechanism now,
  instead of storing this data in Trigger object.

Testing done:
- Unit tests were expanded and are passing
- dbus setters for Sensors and Thresholds are working and modifications
  are reflected by calling appropriate getters.

Signed-off-by: Szymon Dompke <szymon.dompke@intel.com>
Change-Id: I7a14c15a30d78ce872342b5f938aba43c77be9c0

Is this map can be replaced by unordered_map? Unordered_map is smaller and has more efficient underlaying mechanism for insert and access, I suggest to consider it if you do not need sorting of SensorDetails elements.
There wont be much elements in map, probably we won't notice any difference.
I vote for efficiency, and unordered map won't have any cons in this use case.

It seems that sensorName should not be modifiable in here, by introducing reference in the lambda you increase efficiency of this code by risking protection of the variable - I would vote to keep it captured by value as before.
I agree, we should be const correct when possible.
As above - please consider using unordered_map instead.
Done
Are there any cons against moving sensors into oldSensors instead of copying it?
copy is needed because Threshold is unregistering oldSensors which are no longer used
Unregistering was the main reason here. I also wanted to increase security by working on a copy instead of updating it in place. We are copying pointers, so it is not as expensive.
Ack
Is this include really needed here?
Done
Can this one be moved as well?
Done
Why check against numeric alternative and negate? You could just check against discrete and get direct result.

> Why check against numeric alternative and negate? You could just check against discrete and get direct result.

Guessing it comes from that LabeledThresholdParam contains also monostate for discrete (discrete trigger works as specified or changed)?
Exactly, holding monostate in thresholdsParam means that this is Discrete OnChange thresholds, which still counts as Discrete.
This is very long function, maybe you could split it into a few smaller modules, IMO such sliced routine would be much easier to read and understand.
Done
auto?
Done
Are there any cons against moving currentThresholds into oldThresholds instead of copying it?

I think it is more secure this way. If, for any reason, following code would throw an exception (memory allocation is one possibility) currentSensors won't be modified, and service would still work properly.
Ack
Vector capacity reservation for a single element only should not be needed.
Done

Seems that isCurrentOnChange is same for all items in labeledDiscreteThresholdParams, maybe you  could extract it to separate section as a separate condition instead checking this flag every loop in here?
Done
Are there any cons against moving currentSensors into oldSensors instead of copying it?

I think it is more secure this way. If, for any reason, following code would throw an exception (memory allocation is one possibility) currentSensors won't be modified, and service would still work properly.
Ack

There are several repeats of this construct with holds_alternative, and IMO in this form it obfuscates the code, maybe you could replace/create something like isTriggerThresholdDiscrete but for LabeledThresholdParam?
I made a helper method, what do you think about it?

IMO to much work to gain slightly more readable code, if you also need to pass the alternative type to the wrapper then maybe it is better to keep it as it was before by checking via std::holds_alternative in place.
However if you decide to stay with the wrapper then I suggest to rename it to sth like 'isElementsOfType', you have std::vector given as collection to check, and in vector all elements have same type.
Making such checker would result in looping twice over the collection, so I would leave it like that. But I also removed unnecessary if statements to further improve readability
Ack
nit: IMO the name of this struct is confusing, could you use more substantial name to better understand its meaning of handling both discrete trigger and numeric trigger common operations?
changed to ThresholdOperations
Ack
Are there any cons against moving instead of copying it?
Same as in other update methods, I opted to use copy for safety concerns. Also, same as in OnChange update method, this helps with unregistering unused sensors.
Ack
unused
Done
extra ;
Done
move to variable to increase readability
Done

nit: make_shared<std::vector<std::string>>(names) or make_shared<std::vector<std::string>>(std::move(names)) will do the same
